div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7357] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged, as if the voyage were commending at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibralter, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Malls arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
The Sea Fares are:-
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

div.head: INSTITUTE OF MASSAGE
div.p: As practiced in the Faculty of the Royal University of Berlin. Under the management of Sister H. Zandt.
Telephone No. 667. Alexandria: 9, Rue Toussoun Pasha.
Consultation: 7-12 a.m. for ladies and children, 2-5 p.m. for gentlemen.
Following Maladies are treated:
Diseases of Abdonimal Organs: Dyspepsis, Catarrh, Dilatation of stomach, Diarrhea, etc.
Affection of the nervous system and their complications: Anaesthesia, Hyperesthesis, Neuralgia, Neurasthenia, Paralysis, Insomnia, Sciatica, etc.
Constitutional Diseases: Araemia, Obesity, Gout, Diabetes, etc.
Diseases of the Muscles: Contracture, Rheuma- tisms, Contusions (bruise), Atrophies, etc.
Diseases of joints and bones: Arthritis, Dis- articulations, Sprains, Fractures, Ankyloses, etc.
Special diseases of women: Abdominal fix- ations and Displacement of the Genital Organs.
Deviations of the vertebral column: Scoliosis, Hunch-back, ______, etc.
Cosmetic massage: Beautifying the face and body. Wrinkles, enlarged pores and all facial blemished removed.
Vibratory and Thure-Brandt massage.
Electricy in all its forms.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh-Alexandria
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
G. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, CAIRO
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolic. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle a manager. Handsome covered promenade verande, 8 yards long. Highest class cuisince, electric light throughout, and lifts.
English comforts, Rooms and apartments at prices to suit, every one.
For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: IMPORTANT NOTICE.
MARTELL COGNAC.
div.p: M. H. DEMIRGIAN BEY, General Agent for this important House, warns the public to beware of Imitations, and to examine the labels, corks, and capsules.
The principal importers of this well-known Brand are

div.head: MARSEILLE GRAND HOTEL DU LOUVRE & PAIX
WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.

div.head: Callard & Bowser's BUTTER - SCOTCH
div.p: (The Celebrated Sweet for Children).
Really wholesome Confectionary
This popular English Sweetmeat can be obtained at:
Mr. Caronis, Anglo-American Stores, Port-Said.
Mr. Demetriades, Port-Said.
Messrs. Tancred Bonnici & Co., Port-Said.
The Patisserie de la Bourse, Rue Cherif Pasha Alexandria.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT ALEXANDRIA, (Kom-el-Nadours. Observatory.)
div.p: REMARKS.
There has been a distinct change in teh weather since our last. Heavy rain fall n Monday and it has been dull at inter- vals since. The glass is now rising.

div.head: SUBSCRIPTIONS.
div.p: Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231 1/2 per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six motnhs P.T. 136 1/2 (£1.8s), three months P.T. 95 (0.19s.).
H.H.- Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENTS.
div.p: P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages or Deaths, not axceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news collumn P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

div.head: SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS
div.p: are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, ROWLAND SNELLING, Alexandria.
London Offices- 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
The Egyptian Gazette can be obtained in London at our offices, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs MAY & WILLIAMS, 160 Piccadilly, W.
The "Egyptian Gazette" is printed on paper manufactured and supplied by the London Paper Mills Co., Limited (Sales office: 27, Cannon Street, E.C.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English daily paper, establshed 1888.
Editor and Manager - - R. Shellire
Price: One Piastre Tariff.

div.head: OUR VISITOR.
div.p: Two of the greatest, if not the very greatest, of his Majesty's Pro-Consuls, have met to- gether for a brief period in this land. Lord Curzph, after a short stay in Cairo as the guest of Lord Cromer, has left us to con- tinue his journey home after quitting the scene of his Viceregal labours, and after sacrificing his physical health and, latterly, his happiness, on the altar of patriotic duty. In an age when self-seeking is not unknown even among statesmen of high quality Lord Curzon has concentrated all his endeavours on the consolidation and development of that wonder- ful creation, the rule of a handful of his fellow- countrymen over a fifth or a sixth of the world's inhabitants. That was the mission he undertook when he first went to India, but long before, with the thoroughness which has marked his public career throughout, he sedu- lously prepared for its accomplishment by persistent study of whatever Asiatic problems touched the ground plan of his coming cam- paign. When he gave up the brilliant posi- tion he had won for himself at home some wondered at his decision; it seemed to them that he was surrendering the substance of per- sonal greatness for what might easily prove an evanescent shadow. But those friendly critics had never plumbed the inner depths of Lord Corzon's idiosyncrasy. He had, of course, great ambitions and far-reaching aspiration, of a more or less personal charac- ter; no statesman worthy of the name is unequipped with longings for permanent fame. But it stands to the lasting credit of the retir- ed Viceroy that from the date of his arrival in India he unswervingly devoted himself to the promotion of that country's most vital inte- rests, political, military, and commercial. He was the builder; he left it to poste- rity to prenounce on his skill in adapting to modern requirements the almost miracu- lous ediface founded by those immortals, the two Wellesleys, Clive, and Hastings. Lord Curzon will have no occasion to wait long for that national judgment; indeed it has already delivered in the universal regret what circumstances should have conspired to abbreviate his retention of the Vicereyship. ____ it is a safe prediction that when he lands in England, he will be quickly made to feel that no living British statesman holds higher posi- tion in the national esteem that the great Pro- Consul who, as a last sacrifice, gave up his career on what he regarded as a point of duty.

div.head: RUSSIAN REVOLUTION. SERIOUS SITUATION AT SEVASTOPOL. ARMY IN REVOLT.

div.p: The latest accounts from Sevastopol vary as regards details, but they seem to indicate that the mutiny is subsiding.
(Reuter)
The events at Sevastopol exceed in gravity all recent events.
(Havas)

The situation at Sevastopol is very obscure, but it appears that the mutiny is of a revolu- tionary character. It began by the rews of the Panteleimon and Otchakoft hoisting the red flag on the 24th November. They then landed and held a meeting at which a deputation of a Brest regiment swore that the whole regiment would defend the sailors to their utmost. Both soldiers and sailors afterwards paraded the streets waving red flags.

Admiral Pisareviki was wounded while in the act of ordering the troops to fire on the mutineers. Several officers were killed and many arrested. The two vessels are still flying red flags, and the fortress artillery have refus- ed to fire upon them.
(Reuter)

The Panteleimon is now in the hands of the authorities, but the mutinied crew and soldiers have shut themselves up in one of the bar- racks. It is desired to attack them, but it is feared that the artillery men may join them. A part of the Odessa garrison is disposed to make common cause with the mutineers.
(Reuter)
The president and numerous members of the peasants congress here have been arrested owing to incendiary speeches. The governor- General has been dismissed for allowing them.
(Reuter)

The attitude of the army is the most serious feature in the situation. It is admitted here that a spirit of revolt pervades the whole army from Vladivostok to the Baltic. The Manchu- rian forces are in a condition of almost open rebellion. The garrison of this city has form- ulated demands involving the complete remo- delling of the conditions of service. Business is at a standstill.
(Reuter)
Thousands of Russian prisoners who have arrived from Japan have mutinied. They at- tacked the Officers' Club yesterday, killing and wounding four officers. The Cossacks have restored order.
(Reuter)

div.head: UNIVERSAL SUFFRAGE IN AUSTRIA HUGE DEMONSTRATION.

div.p: To-day the Socialists organised a huge or- derly universal suffrage demonstration on the occasion of the opening of the Reichsrath. Two hundred thousand men were present. A deputation was favorably received by the Go- vernment.
(Reuter)
A demonstration, in which, it is estimated, 200.000 persons took part, has been held here in favor of universal suffrage. A similar demonstration took place at Prague.
(Havas)
Mr. Austin Chamberlan, speaking at Red- ditch, said that, so far as his experiences went, there had been no Government crisis, neither was there a crisis in the party.
(Reuter)

Speaking at Newcastle under Lyne, Sir E. Grey said that there would be no substantial difference between the Irish policy of Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman and Lord Rose- bery in a future Liberal Cabinet, but that it was not honest to make use of votes ob- tained upon other issues to reverse the ver- dict of 1895 as to Home Rule.
(Reuter)

The "Daily News" is confident concerning the situation, and delcares that it is relieved because of Lord Rosebery's declaration, as it means that he will be excluded from the next Government, and he is not an easy man to work with.
(Reuter)

div.head: GERMAN WEST AFRICA. HOTTENTOT LEADER SURRANDERS.

div.p: The Hottentot leader Isask Witboi and 17 chiefs have surrendered to the Germans.
(Reuter)
The King of Greece has started for home.
(Reuter)

div.head: MACEDONIAN CRISIS. DETACHMENS DISEMBARKED AT MITYLENE. CUSTOM HOUSE SEIZED.

div.p: The International Squadron has arrived at Mitylene.
(Reuter)
The International Squadron has entered the port. 400 men landed and occupied the Cus- tom house. The Turkish garrison retired to the barracks.
(Havas)
The International Fleet has disembarked detachments which have seized the Custom House.
(Reuter)

The International Fleet will not take any further action pending the Beyrem festival, which is ending on Thursday evening. Then it will occupy Tenedos. The Ports meanwhile continues to suggest some modifications in the demands.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE KAISER AND PEACE. SPEECH AT THE PEICHSTAG.

div.p: The significant passage of the Emperor William's speech at the opening of the Reich- stag, was that the relations with all the Powers were correct, and with most of them good and friendly.

He added that he sympathised keenly with the efforts of the Tsar to re-organise the internal affairs of Russia, and that he is gratified by the conclusion of an agreement with regard to the question of Morocco, which originated in the tendency to ignore German interests. He regarded peace as a sacred thing, but the times demand the strengthening of defences against unrighteous attacks.
(Reuter)
In his speech at the opening of the Reich- stag, the Emperor William said that he was pleased over the Moroccan agreement, which saves the interests and the honor of France and Germany
(Havas)

div.head: Sheep-pox.
div.p: Sheep-pox is reported to be prevalent in the Minieh district.

div.head: Abyssinian Bank.
div.p: The personnel of the Abyssinian Bank, thir- teen strong, leaves for Adis Abeba on Friday next.

div.head: Statistical Bureau.
div.p: The new Statistical Bureau will be composed of one director, one inspector, and the usual subordinate staff.

div.head: New Time-Table.
div.p: The State Railway Administration has issued a new time-table which comes into force on December 1.

div.head: The Mail.
div.p: The Brindisi mail will arrive at Alexandria this afternoon and will be distributed at the G.P.O. at 5 p.m.

div.head: Pharmacies Inspectorate.
div.p: An inspectorate for phramacies has been created. It will consist of one first-class phar- macist, one head clerk, and one subordinate clerk.

div.head: The Opera Season.
div.p: The Italian opera company which is to per- form at Alexandria and Cairo this season is expected to arrive by the Italian steamer on Sunday.

div.head: Moslem Benevolent Society.
div.p: The Moslem Benevolent Society has already distributed a sum of P.T. 22,500 among indi- gent Moslems to aid them to share in the festivites of Beyram.

div.head: Lots Turcs.
div.p: The Imperial Ottoman Bank informs us that bond No. 874,650 was the winner of the "gro lot" in Monday's drawing of the Ottoman Railway Lottery.

div.head: Wives Poison their Husband.
div.p: Two women of Nag Hamadi have been arrested on the charge of having caused their spouse's death by introducing poison into cakes which they made for him to eat.

div.head: British Warships.
div.p: Another British man-of-war is expected at Alexandria from Port Said during the course of the day. H.M.S. Carnarvon dressed ship yesterday on the occasion of Beyram, as did also several other vessels in port.

div.head: Staff Ride.
div.p: A Staff ride will be held in Cairo between the 3rd and 7th December next. Brig.- General Bullock, C.B., will be umpire in chief, while Bt.-Colonel Bird, D.S.O., will be umpire of the Blue force, and Lieut.-Colonel Markham of the Red force.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: Sixteen ships passed through the Canal on the 24th and 25th inst., of which 10 were British, 1 French, 1 Dutch, 1 Italian, 1 Russian, 1 Danish. The total amount received in dues from the 1st to the 22nd inst. was frs. 8,252,010.43.

div.head: THE BEYRAM FESTIVAL. CELEBRATIONS IN CAIRO.
div.p: Full hotels, swarms of uniforms, and a clouding sky, with a bitter wind: so the Beyram holiday opened in Cairo. It spite of the cold weather and threats of rain the public had made up its mind to enjoy itself. The Mena trams were full early, multitudes went out to Helouan, but the streets were by no means crowded or eve unusually full, though it was holiday, perhaps in consequence of late hours and feasting the night before. Near Abdern a good many people had congregated to watch the arrivals fot the reception, which was, as usual, very largely attended by the higher ranks of the military and civil branches of the Government, by the officers of the Army of Occupation, and those for whom official Egypt- or was it official France 1- has devised the term of "notables."

A very strong official and lay contingent was furnished by Alexandria, provincial no- tables were "up" and staying at all the best hotels, and the rain very considerately held off till near the close of the reception, when a few drops fell and thickened to a steady drizzle that lasted with occasional intermissions well into the afternoon.

The Moslem Benevolent Society gave a fete in the Esbekieh Gardens, which were decorated for the occasion and illuminated at nightfall. All sorts of music was to be heard, conjurors kept a crowd, which contained a large pro- portion of soldiers, amused and cheerful despite a low temperature and wet grass. Acrobats and strong men performed before audiences that increased gradually as the afternoon wore on, and at night came the fireworks and coloured lights. The streets were thoroughly muddy, deep in that peculiarly sticky mud that is so characteristic of Cairo, but no one seemed to care particularly. The Egy[tian is easily pleased, and his calm acqui- escence in all that is, makes him indifferent to a cold and wet Beyram.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive stayed at Koubbeh Palace on Sunday and Monday and came to Cairo for the reception held at Abdeen yester- day at an early hour of the morning. In the afternoon his Highness paid the usual Beyram visit to the Princes, his uncles, and to Ghazi Ahmed Mukhtar Pasha.
The Khedive left Koubbeh for Montazah early to-day.

div.head: THE KHEDIVIAL HOUSEHOLD.
div.p: Ahmed Bay Khairy, Master of Ceremonies to H.H. the Khedive, has resigned his position for family reasons, and also on the ground of ill-health. H.E. Ahmed Pasha Zeki, Grand Master of Ceremonies, has written a letter to Ahmed Bey Khairy expressing the Khedive's regret at the retirement of a faithful servant who had done good service to the Khedivial House.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: Among the decisions taken by the Council of Ministers, which met under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive on Saturday afternoon, were the retirement of Rizkallah Bey Gabrial, of the State Railways Administration, the grant of L.E. 1,400 indemnity to the family of the late Grand Mufti of Egypt, Sheikh Mohamed Abdon, of which L.E. 1,000 is granted to his wife and L.E. 400 to his daughter, and the expropriation of the areas necessary for the construction of a house for the Irrigation Department at Dar el-Rimad, Fayoum, and for the enlargement of the same department's store houses at Zifta.

div.head: LORD CROMER AND THE MISSION.
div.p: We have the pleasure to announce to our readers, says "Al Moayad," that Lord Cromer has intervened in regard to the disputs which recently occured between Moslems and Christ- ians at the American Mission's School at Cairo, on account of a sermon which touched Moslem sentiment. His lordship has seen Dr. Watson, and required him to put an end to the policy of the preachers as regards the Moslem religion. His lordship has a so ordered the Hakamdar of the Cairo police to give the police strict orders as to the manner in which they must act in similar circumstances.

The Mohamedans, continues our contempo- rary, will be pleased to learn of Lord Cromer's great solicitude on their behalf, and the respect he pays to national feelings. We hope, "Al Moayad" concludes, that Lord Cromer's policy will have a good effect upon missionaries in Egypt and that they will learn to be peaceful in future.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: The Lambert company gave a repeat per- formance of Corneille's Le Cid, before leaving the country, at the Zizinia yesterday evening. There was a disappointingly small house, which we think is due to the fact that the perfor- mance itself, it goes without saying, was worthy of the best traditions of the French stage.

div.head: TRAIN TRAFFIC INTERRUPTED WASH-OUT ON UPPER EGYPT LINE.
div.p: The Traffic Manager of the State Railways telegrahs as follows:-

Owing to a wash-out at Masrat El Ghizeh Bridge, situated 200 meters south of Abou El Nomros station, passenger trains to and from stations in Upper Egypt will to-day, and pro- bably to-morrow, run only as far as About El Nomros station, and passengers for stations north or south of that station are hereby informed that they will have to trans-ship at the bridge to another train. Invalids are strongly recommended not to travel until the bridge is repaired.

div.head: STOP PRESS TELEGRAM.
div.p: Owing to accidental failure of irrigation bank, a railway bridge south of Ghizreh endan- gered until water level subsides which may not be for two or three days. Impossible to ascertain extent of damage. Meanwhile passengers have to walk from one train to another across the bridge.
Usual passenger service working but trains are delayed about two hours.
Passengers leaving Cairo by the evening train to south do not reach dining car until about 10 p.m.
Hope to re-establish normal working on Saturday, but this is uncertain.
Goods from stations north of Abou El Nom- ros to stations south of it or vice versa cannot be accepted until further notice.

div.head: REDUCED LIGHTHOUSE DUES.
div.p: From January 1, the lighthouse dues will be reduced from 14 to 10 milliemes per ton up to 800 tons displacement, and from 7 to 5 milliemes per ton on every ton above 800 tons displacement.

div.head: STATE CONTENTIEUX.
div.p: Mr. W.G. Hayter, Substitute to the Conten- tieux at the Ministry of Justice, has been appointed Substitute to the State Conten- tieux in place of the late Maitre Molteni.

div.head: ASSIZE COURTS.
div.p: The degree authorising the establishment of Assize Courts in each of the districts of the Beni Souef, Assiout, and Keneh Tribunals has been made public. Each Court will sit for the first time in January.

div.head: THE SUDAN BUDGET.
div.p: The Sudan Budget Estimates for 1906 amount to L.E. 1,001,706 for revenue against L.E. 915,616 in 1905, including the subsidy received from the Egyptian Government. The expenditiure exactly balances the revenue and includes the sum of L.E. 189,757 paid to the Egyptian War Office for the maintenance of the Egyptian troops in the Sudan.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: The British S.S. Afganistan (namesake of the ill fated vessel which was wrecked about two years ago with the Suskin condensors) has arrived here on her maiden trip to India and has brought a large consignment of railway material and bridges for the Sudan Railway.
Kaimakam Drury Bey, R.N., Controller of Sudan Ports, has arrived from Egypt by the Khedivial mail steamer Rahmanieh.

An English orchestra, which is going to Bombay by the Afghanistan, to play for the session in one of the largest hotels there, gave a concert last night at Government House. No entrance fees were charged, and the place was crowded, a very enjoyable evening being spent. The orchestra consists of 14 per- formers, all males, under Bandmaster Coke.

div.head: IRRIGATION.
div.p: Our Tahta Correspondent writes that there is no sharaki land whatever in the Tahta district this year. The lands have all been cultivated, and wherever one goes luxuriant vegetation is to be seen, arguing well for the drops. Great praise is due to Hussein Bey Wassif the Moudir of Ghirgeh Irrigation directerate, who, with his able staff, has worked wonders.

div.head: A STORMY VOYAGE.
div.p: The captain of the S.S. Cit yof Cambridge, which arrived at Alexandria on Monday, re- ports a very heavy gale in the Bay of Biscay, which did damage to some of the deck fittings, boats, etc., and also swept overboard the deck cargo.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Avon arrived at Liver- pool on Sunday.
The Eller man S.S. Britannia sailed for Liverpool yesterday with passengers and gene- ral cargo, including 4,957 bales cotton.
The S.S. Sailor Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on Friday last, and is due to arrive at Alexadnria, via Tunis and Malta, on or about Dec. 9.
The S.S. City of Cambridge arrived on Monday from Liverpool, Lisbon, Gibralter, and Malta.

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S SMALL DANCE. OPENING OF THE SEASON.
div.p: Quite a number of peopl took part in the small dance at Shepheard's on Saturday night, and though there was a great preponderance of men present, everybody seemed cheery and bent on amusement. Sir Elwin Palmer looked in for a short time, and the Hon. Fred Morgan was very busy among his friends. The Hon. C. James and Mrs. James were there, the latter in a pretty fresh green silk frock draped with lace and velvet. The beautiful Mme Vernon was surrounded, as usual, by her little court, though she did not take part in the dancing; Brigadier-General Bullock, Mr. Webb, and Mr. Leigh Hunt (who is at present staying at Shepheard's), were also onlookers, and among the latest residents we noticed Mr. and Mrs. E.C.G. Porter, who brough a few friends. Mrs. Porter, who has a beautiful, slight figure looked remarkably well in black crepe de chene with a deep lace berthe. There were several other pretty frocks in spite of it being quite an informal occasion and still early in the season. One Empire gown was a filmy black chiffon enriched by a heavy Greek design in black velvet, and hanging from a deep yoke, etc., of cream lace. The velvet trimming outlined the yoke and sleeves, and faint touches of coral pink gave a touch of colour to the lace. A black sequined net had wide insertions and folded ceinture of delicate Pompadeur silk; and a handsome fair woman was magnificent in apricot-coloured "chiffon veleurs" draped with lace. A young girl was wearing a soft grey spotted crepe-de-chene over an under robe of cream chiffon, the crossed drapery of the decollatage being edged with tiny quillings of cream; and there were one or two handsome cream satin gowns draped with lace.

div.head: L'EAU A ALEXANDRIE
div.p: Lots o' French

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Lots o' French
H.H. Prince Djemil Pasha Toursoun left for Paris on Monday.
H.H. Prince Fazil Ozman is staying at Shep- heard's Hotel.
H.E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy is spending Beyram at Mena House.

There was a large number of well-known arrivals by the Hohenzoilern yesterday from Europe, including H.H. Princess Ismail, Count and Countess de Zogheb, M. and Mme N. Siradino, etc. A full list of passengers will be published to-morrow.
The marriage arranged between Mr. Percy Machell and Countess Victoria Glechen will take place at the Chapel Royal, St. James's Palace, on the 7th December, at twelve o'clock.
Sir William Garstin will return to Cairo at the end of December.
Saba Pasha and Chitty Bey have arrived at Cairo from Alexandria.
M. Maspero will leave for a tour in Upper Egypt between the 8th and 10th prox.
Mr. Somers-Clarke, the well-known architect, is leaving for Mehimed this evening.
Professor Flinders Petrie and Mrs. Petris are staying at the Hotel du Nil, Cairo.
M. de Hoelske, Russian Commis ioner on the Caisse de la Dette has returned to Cairo.
We regret to hear of the death of the wife of Mr. Philemon Hallam Tuck, brother of Judge Tuck, of which sad event information has just come by cable from Baltimore, Mary- land, U.S.A.

The Hon. Mrs. Lindley, wife of the Second Secretary in the Diplomatic Service, who has spent most of the autumn in Invernesshire, has left England for Cairo. Mrs. Lindley is leaving her baby in the Highlands, but her elder little girl comes out to Egypt with her.
The Hon. Francis Lindley is expecting an appointment in the newly-constituted British Embassy at Tokyo, in which case he will prob- ably be stationed in Japan for several years.
Among others who are coming out to Egypt are Major F.I. Ricarde-Seaver, Lord and Lady Talbot de Malahide, and the Earl and Count- ess of Leitrir. The latter party leave Mar- seille on December 15.

The Baron and Baronness of Zoylem have left Cairo for Tunis, where they propose to make a short stay. The Baron and Baroness have been touring in Sicily, Greece, and -despite the execrable raod- in Palestine in a 24 h.p. de Dion motor car.

The marriage of Miss Cohen and Mr. Elward Frieman of Constantinople, took place yes- terday at Cairo, followed by a reception at the Continental Hotel, at which nearly all the chief Israelite fmilies of the Capital were represented. The guests were received by Mr. Coronel, soucin of the bride, and the hotel presented unusual animation till 5 o'clock. In the evening a dance was given in honor of the happy pair, and many fresh and elaborate gowns graced the occasion.
Prof. and Mrs. Simpson, who arrived yester- day by the Hohenzollern, are going up river with a party on the dahabieh Serapis.
Sir Ernest Cassel has contributed £2,000 to Queen Alexandra's Fund for the relief of the unemployed.

div.head: ARRIVALS
div.p: Per S.S. City of Cambridge, arrived from Liverpool and Malta on Monday: Miss A. Clark, Mr. and Mrs. D.M. Dunlop, Mr. C.D. Cocks, Miss A. Spratt, Mr. E.H. Jones, Miss E. Turner, Mrs. de Costs, Mrs. Ely, Miss Cooks, Mr. M Wardlaw, Mr. Senesi, Mrs. Sciortino, Miss Sciortino and Miss Violet Sciortino, Miss Sciortino, Mr. and Mrs. Cu- mesux, Miss Cumeaux and Miss Cumeaux.

div.head: DEPARTURES.
div.p: Per S.S. Semiramis sailed Saturday for Trieste:- Mr. and Mrs. Cramwell, M.P. Vigny, M. della Riccia, M. Dutilmy, M. Malone, M. Peritz, Mr. A.H. Cobbe, Mr. H.C. Sloley, Mr. S. Edwards, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis, Mr. and Mrs. Logan, Mr. J.O. Roishail, Mr. Yurgens, Mlle J. Perez, Dr. A. Lesl, Dr. E. Saldenks, Capt. Hugo de Laredo, Capt. Lloyd; Mr. A Dekan, M.G. Weinberger, M. Seores- gat, Mlle C. Fuchs, M.A. Tiano, M.A. Luipt, M.I. Brann, M.G. Mele, M. and Mme Kula- chek and two children, M.H. Basten, M.P. Volmaher, M. Hoffmann, and 81 third-class passengers.

div.head: IRRIGATION ENGINEERING.
div.docAuthor: By Sir Hanburt Brown, K.C.M.G., late Insepctor-General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, and formerly in Upper Egypt.
div.head: IV.
div.p: To deal with the large bodies of water that have to be distributed over the extensive areas of a basin chain, perfect control over the water at all points is necessary. This is only to be obtained by a sufficiency of regulating works, such as head sluices, to draw the water from the river into the feeder canal; basin sluices to admit water from the canal into the basins; regulators or escapes in the basin cross banks, to pass on the water and regulate the level in the basins above them; and escapes to dis- charge the water back into the river. The arrangements of a basin system should be devised with a two-fold object, namely, to get the full benefit of a good flood and to guard against the dificiencies of a low flood. In a good flood as much water as possible should be passed through the basins, so as to obtain a maximum deposit of the fertilising matter which is carried by flood water. To effect this, the head sluice of the feeder canal should not be closed when the basins are full, but should be left open, and the levels in the basins re- gulated by the opening of their escapes to the necessary extent. In this way a quantity of water is admitted to the basins in excess of that required to fill them, and, as the current in the wide expanse of water is imperceptible, all the silt is thrown down before the water passes away again, fertilizing the land surface for the crop which will follow the retirement of the waters. To guard against the deficiencies of a low flood, the canals, as has been stated above, should be dug so as to give a suffiency of water, even in the most unfavorable years, to cover all the lands, if only for a short time, so that the ground may take up sufficient moisture for maturing the coming crop- an important matter, inasmuch as, if the opportu- nity of soaking the land during the flood is lost, the one crop that flood lands produce in the year has no chance of being sown. It will be easily understood that in bad years- in fact in most years- the land near the point where a basin feeder takes off from the river cannot be reached by the flood water entering the feeder. So these lands are served by the canals belonging to the chain of basins next above, their high-level water being carried in syphon under the basin feeder of the next lower chain. Provision is also made for pass- ing on water from one basin to the next so that, in case there remain some lands untouched by the water when the time for emptying the basins comes, their inundation may be completed by raising the water level in each basin in succession by the help of the volume discharged into it from the basin next above it.

The basin system is, however, destined to give place to the perennial system of irriga- tion, whereby not only are two crops a year raised instead of one, but the average value of each crop is hgiher than that of the single crop grown on basin lands. In Upper Egypt, since the construction of the Assonen Dam, a very considerable proportion of the pre- viously existing basins has already been con- verted to perennially irrigatied land. Conse- quently, the method of irrigation by inunda- tion is losing some of its importance as an object of study. Moreover, what has been written above describes in a general way the principle of distribution of water by basins, so that no further description need be given of the working of this system. Those who may have, hereafter, to control such irriga- tion will naturally study the official records and standard books on irrigation, which con- tain a full record of the past twenty years experience of responsible officials and the con- clusions arrived at.

Let us return once more to the consideration of the subject of perennial irrigation. The possibility that the available supply of water might be insufficient for the whole of a given area requiring irrigation has been referred to above. The insufficiency may not be recognised in the first instance during the period of design, but may be felt after the canals have been in working order for some time, as a result of an unexpected expansion of the cultivated area depending upon the canal. Such has been the case in Egypt, where, in con- sequence of the remarkable development of the country and the reclamation of uncultivated areas, the summer supply of the Nile, at last, proved insufficient, when fully utilised, to meet the demand of the increasing areas of crops depending on it for their irrigation. Con- sequently it became necessary to study the question of how to supplement the summer supply of the Nile. As, during the flood and winter seasons, a small proportion only of the river discharge is utilised, while the greater amount runs into the sea, the problem resolved itself into one of storage of this surplus water at those seasons. And so the Assouan Dam was built, and a reservoir formed above it in the valley of the Nile itself, wherein the summer flood and winter surplus is stored for use in the following summer as an addition to the low supply; but even with this addition the summer supply is still insufficient to meet the demand, and additional means of supplement- ing it are being studied. the problems connect- ed with this question are somewhat intricate but highly interesting. They are clearly stated in an article by Sir William Garstin, which appeared in the September number of the "Nineteenth Century" under the heading "Some Problems of the Upper Nile."

div.head: ANOTHER MONOPOLY. ZEITOUN-MATARIEH WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: To the editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Eight months ago the residents of the Zeitoun and Matarieh district were inveigled into taking the company's water on the distinct understanding that they were to be charged o fixed amount based on the number of square metre contained in their respective properties. The price fixed by the Water Company was accepted by the majority of the residents, who relied upon the company's good faith when assuring them that no charge would be made in the system then instituted for assessing the cost of water consumed.

A few days ago the Water Company issued a circular to the subscribers informing tham of their intention to place meters and that water would in future be charged for at the rate of P.T. 68.7 for the first 50 cubic meters and 51 metres and upwards at the rate of P.T. 1 per metre per month, and rental for the meters at an all-around average of about P.T. 10. Thsi works out at about double the charge levied by the company hitherto, and is no less than 82% dearer than the subscribers residing at Ramleh pay the Alexandria Water Co.
Most of the residents have given up their sakkiehs and have in many instances gone to considerable expense in laying down water-pipe installations for their garden and house.

The company's action at the present junc- ture of affairs is manifestly a gross abuse of equity. Moreover an examination of the com- pany's report and balance-sheet shows that the receipts per 100 metres of water amounts to P.T. 85, whilst the expenses, including the board of administration, are only P.T. 20; there is thus a profit of P.T. 63 per 100 metres of water, equivalent to the enormous percentage of 335%.
The Assiout concession shows 205% profit.

Having regard to the special condition which obtained in the country formerly, the policy of the Egyptian Government in granting monopolies was no doubt a wise one and served a useful purpose, but surely the Govern- ment of the present day, even supposing that they deem it expedient to grant further mono- polies, should apply the necessary clauses to safeguard the interests of the inhabitants affected by them.
Water is one of the necessities of life and the result of the latest decision of the Water Company is already felt in a distinct upward tendency in rents in Zeitoum.

Instea of increasing their price the Water Company should decrease it. Even if it were reduced to 5 milliemes per metre they would still earn a profit of over 100%, a rate exceeding the wildest dreams of the heads of the most flourishing commercial concerns in Egypt or elsewhere.
Subscriber,

div.head: THE PROTECTION OF ANIMALS.
div.p: To the editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,- During my short residence in this town, the one thing I find characteristically cruel, if the maltreatment of the animals, chiefly of horses. It has been my daily misfor- tune to see these poor creatures trying to draw the heaviest burdens, of which the weight is obviously higher than their power. This burden is often composed of building materials, or, sometimes, of Arab women, who sit down on the long carts by dozens and more, perhaps, ignorant of the cruelty they are caus- ing. Under these sad circumstances, no wonder if it has been a common scene in the streets, the falling down of the horses, who, exasperat- ed and bloody as they are, again and again are whipped to work even in their impotence. I think the whip must be turned to the man, and not to the animal. This fact is so obvious and cruel, that it ought to call the attention of all those who are concerned. The other day I met a friend, a fanatic member of Animals Protection Association, who was carefully read- ing the annual report of the association, and declraing the good done by this association. I don't know if there is any of the kind in this town, but I can surely assume that it is high time to look after these oppressed and mal- treated animals.
Leon Larentz.
Alexandria.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION. BEEF AND MUTTON.
div.p: Tenders will be received at the Head Quarters Offices, Cairo, until 12 o'clock noon on Friday 1st December 1905, for the supply of Beef and Mutton to the Army of Occupation at Cairo and Alexandria, for 12 months from 1st January 1906.
Forms of Tender and all information may be obtained at the above Offices on application.
Envelopes containing Tenders should be addressed to "The General Officer Command- ing, Cairo," and marker on the outside "Tender for Meat."
The General Officer Commanding does not bind himself to accept the lowest of any tender.
(Signed) A.E. Delavoye, Major, A.S.C., for Chief Staff Officer.
Head Quaters,

div.head: Alexandria & Ramleh Railway, Cy. Limited. AVIS
div.p: L'Alexandria & Ramleh Railway Cy. Ltd. a l'honneur de rappeler au Public que le dernier delai pour l'echange des anciens carnets de 50 billets qui ont ete supprimes depuis le 1er Novembre, expire le 30 du mois courant.

Par consequent, les detenteurs des anciens carnets sont pries de vouloir bien se presenter aux Bureaux de la Direction (Gare de Ramleh), pour les echanger contre de nouveaux carnets ayant un nombre equivalent de coupons.
A partir du 1er Decembre 1905, les anciens carnets non echanges n'auront plus aucune valeur. La Direction.

OFFRES

Un jeune homme offrant de bonnes referen- ces et une garatie de £1000 demande un emploi d'encaisseur ou de caissier.
Un comptable connaissant le francais et l'allemand cherche un emploi.
Une maison de nouveautes du Caire demande deux demoiselles employees.
Une maison de vente demande un jeune em- ploye, ayant un an de commerce.
Un comptable pouvant tenir la comptabilite en francais et en arabe cherche un emploi.
Un employe disposant de deux heures par jour, demande a tenir une petite comp- tabilite.
N.B.- Pour tous renseignements d'adresser au Siege Social de la Societe, Rue Mosquee Attarine No. 21.
Le Secretariat est ouvert les Lundi, Mercredi et Vendredi de 7 h. 1/2 a 8 h. 1/2 du soir.
Les insertions ci-dessus sont faites gratuite ment par les soins de la Societe et seuls les societaires peuvent en beneficier.
Les personnes qui font des offres ou des demandes sont prices de joindre un timbre a leur lattre, sinon il ne leur sera fait aucune reponse.
Nous croyons utile de faire remarquer que pour etre admis dans la Societe, les employes doivent:
1. Avoir travaille au moins 6 mois a Alex- andrie;
2. Jouir d'une bonne reputation;
3. Etre munis de bons certificats.
